Fields.DialogueText: *KNOCK*
Capitaine? Are you awake?
... Yes, I'm awake. You can come in.
Are you sure? I don't want to be rude, Capitaine.
I just said I was awake, didn't I? Of course you can come in.
You are not fooling me! I heard you cough. Are you sure that you aren't sick?

Fields.MenuText: I didn't cough. I was just clearing my throat.
I promise that I'm fine. I care about my crew and wouldn't expose them to something like that.
You caught me. I confess that... I have the bubonic plague!

Fields.DialogueText: If you say so. I'm trusting you here.
I appreciate that reassurance, Capitaine.
AAAGH! I KNEW IT!
Eh bien - I am coming in now.
Well?
Stop holding your breath. I told you everything is fine.
Marseillaise? You're turning blue.
Mmph?
Yes. Blue.
Whew... All right. I am all right. You understand my abundance of caution, Capitaine. My herbs can only do so much against the miasma of the sick.
If I start feeling miasmic, you'll be the first to know. What did you need to tell me?
Oui. I have-
*ALARM*
Aha! The Morganas are here! Aux armes, citoyens!
I guess I'll find out later...
@BATTLE
Marseillaise, please stop screaming! I was just kidding.
C'est inapproprié, Capitaine! No more jokes about such things!
I promise.
Hrm.
Marseillaise, I need a report on our repair efforts from the last Morgana combat.
I am, as you can see, quite well. Repairs are completed.
Very well.
I do, however, have concerns of my own. Capitaine, si'l vous plaît, drink this tea.
What?
Mon Dieu! It is far worse than I feared. Your illness has already affected your hearing.

Fields.MenuText: You're the herbalist around here, so I'm in good hands. Down the hatch!
Smells like... dirt.
HUH? I CAN'T HEAR YOU!

Fields.DialogueText: Trust me implicitly, mon Capitaine.
It will taste slightly worse than dirt. However, it will be quite beneficial to you.
DRINK IT! RAPIDEMENT!
Gulp... urk... the taste is quite...
Earthy?
Let's go with earthy. And strong. It, uh, reminds me of you.
It is for your health, Capitaine. We cannot fall to illness, or we will surely fall to Morganas.
Thanks for taking care of me, Marseillaise.
*ALARM*
Here they come! I hope you digest that tea in time. Jump up and down to get it into your body faster!
I'm not going to jump up and down, for-
Do it! They are almost here!
We'll compromise. I'll jog to the bridge.
@BATTLE
I am concerned about our food.
Are we running out?
Worse. Our food is... bad.
You mean it spoiled.
Non, non, rien de tout ça, mais... It is just... not very good. A French ship should be ashamed of such cuisine.

Fields.MenuText: We have more important things to worry about. Make sure we have enough ammunition.
It's not like a revolutionary to be picky.
Call Command immediately! We're all going to starve to death!

Fields.DialogueText: We have plenty of it, but it won't matter if our crew is malnourished.
Command have the budget for better than this! I'm asking for our fair share.
Don't tease me like that, Capitaine. I take our crew's nutrition and health seriously.
I care about the crew, but I'm not convinced that we're poisoning them just yet.
I will keep researching this.
You go ahead and do that, Marseillaise. I'll be on the bridge.
Of course, Capitaine.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Zut, could they come at a less convenient time?
Capitaine, I need to speak to you. It's urgent.
Just to be clear, I do not have pneumonia, tuberculosis, or bubonic plague.
Formidable! I am glad my tea was helpful.
That's not exactly what I was trying to-
Forgive me for interrupting, but it is urgent. What do you think of the soup on board the ship?

Fields.MenuText: It's not bad at all. You're stocked with adequate supplies.
I usually don't eat it.
It's terrible, even as rations.

Fields.DialogueText: Just as I feared. Your palate has become completely insensitive!
This could explain your terrible health. You need quality soup.
I agree! It is criminal to call it soup.
What's your solution, then?
Our bad soup will lead to worse health. We require something of a better quality to keep us all healthy.
So, your urgent matter is... soup.
Oui, it is. We need to serve a delicious bouillabaisse that will keep us in top condition for warfare!
If you feel this is important, I can request new supplies next time we're in port.
I do not think Command can provide what we require quickly enough. I propose we acquire fresh ingredients ourselves.
So... you want us to become a fishing vessel... and catch our ingredients.
Exactement! It is a revolutionary proposition, Capitaine. The higher-ups have deemed these rations worthy. The people find them otherwise, so they will replace them!
I'm sure some of the crew would welcome this new pastime.
*ALARM*
But Morganas will always take priority.
You know how I feel about fighting on an empty stomach. Aux armes, citoyens!
@BATTLE
Please get out of the way. If I can't see the charts, I can't review the navigation plan.
Non! Not yet. I must tell you something before you look at those charts.
Unless what you're about to tell me will radically change the way I read these charts, I fail to see the point here.
There is no need to be cross, Capitaine. I am helping-
Move aside, please. Oof. There we go.
I am helping you to see something critical. Now, you will notice certain areas I have marked on the charts.
Did you scribble in crayon all over my charts!?
Non! I merely outlined areas where we should fish for rascasse rouge.

Fields.MenuText: Why do I care about fishing?
These charts are a mess, Marseillaise.
We need those for the soup, right?

Fields.DialogueText: For the soup, of course! You agreed we would get fresh ingredients for it.
Stop complaining like a fussy baby, Capitaine. It is not so messy.
For the bouillabaisse, oui! We must remain one step ahead of hunger lest it ensnare us.
To make our bouillabaisse, we need the right fish. Rascasse rouge should be abundant in areas that are not far from our patrol route.
I have marked them on the charts.
All over the charts. In red crayon. I thought we agreed that Morganas would still be our primary concern.
They are, but the seas are clear right now. We can surely-
*ALARM*
Zut! Morganas...
Sounds like the fishing trip is-
Do not say a word, Capitaine. This is not settled!
@BATTLE
Ma'am, Morganas have been spotted to the east.
Alert the crew, Capitaine.
@BATTLE
Do you see anything yet, Capitaine?
Calm seas and a clear horizon, but I didn't need to climb all the way up the superstructure to see that. Come on down, already.
Belles have better eyesight than humans. Besides, you know what I mean.

Fields.MenuText: Morganas? Not a single one in sight.
Rascasse rouge? I don't see any fish leaping onto the ship, no.
A cure for your soup fixation? Nope. Nothing yet.

Fields.DialogueText: That is good news, but that is not what I mean.
Of course not, silly Capitaine. I know that is not how it works.
One day soon we will look back on your ridicule and laugh. Over perfect bowls of bouillabaisse.
I am talking about good places to start fishing.
I suppose we could slow down.
Oui? You mean it? I will get the nets ready!
Just be careful not to hurt yourself. And as soon as we see Morganas, we're going to stop fishing and start fighting.
Enfin! Nous aurons enfin de la bonne nourriture!
Just remember what I said. Any Morganas and we stop.
Oui, oui, of course!
Marseillaise, are you down here?
Oui, I am in the torpedo room!
Ugh, it definitely smells like... seafood.
I have struck the first blow for the people! Our crew is one step closer to delicious soup.
You've also struck a few nerves.
Oh?
The torpedo chief is going to lose his mind when he sees that you turned the torpedo room into a...
A what, exactly?

Fields.MenuText: A cold storage room.
A fish market.
A place where... people... store fish... that they've caught. You know what I mean!

Fields.DialogueText: I wish it were colder in here. I have to hurry so the fish do not spoil, and there is only so much salt to preserve it.
Non? The torpedo room is already a place for "fish", if you like that word for torpedoes.
Ha! Do not make me laugh. I have much work to do.
Besides, it won't be like this for long. I will have the fish moved to our iceboxes as soon as they are cleaned.
And then clean the torpedo room.
It will be done.
Oh, and one more thing.
Quoi?
Nice job. This looks like a great catch.
Merci, Capitaine!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
And will you look at that? I am already prepared to fire these torpedoes!
Capitaine, I cannot decide on our next course of action.
Command doesn't have any new orders for us. We're going to continue our local combat patrol.
That is not quite what I meant. I was talking about the bouillabaisse.

Fields.MenuText: This is a warship. We should be thinking about stopping Morganas.
What's the problem?
Why are you so obsessed with soup?

Fields.DialogueText: And just how will we stop Morganas if we are suffering from malnutrition?
You might be able to help with it, Capitaine.
We must all stay healthy, Capitaine! No revolution was ever run on diseased feet.
We still need more ingredients, but I am not certain where to look next.
Don't ask me. You're the expert, right?
I need a way to decide...
Zut! Why did I not think of this before! My cards!
Cards? How is a poker game going to solve that?
Have you forgotten already? My tarot cards are not playing cards.
Ah, right.
Let's find a table, and we can-
*ALARM*
Sounds like it will have to wait. Get to action stations!
@BATTLE
We're not starving, you know.
It's only a slight exaggeration.
I have detected several contacts coming over the horizon, Capitaine.
Let's show them what we can do.
Aux armes, citoyens!
@BATTLE
That last fight rattled a few rivets. All compartments, make your damage control reports to the bridge.
Capitaine! I have dire news!
How bad is the damage?
Quoi?
Your damage report. You said it was dire?
Non, non... I am talking about my tarot card reading.

Fields.MenuText: I ordered damage reports, not fortune telling!
Damage control first, tarot cards later.
Oh, good. Damage control reports are so boring.

Fields.DialogueText: The damage has been addressed to my satisfaction. I promise I would tell you if anything was wrong, Capitaine.
Excusez-moi, Capitaine. Oui, of course. Damage control efforts are satisfactory.
Hmm. I suspect you are being... sarcastique.
Just minutes after a battle, and you're already thinking about your tarot cards.
I have many passions. Fighting Morganas is only one of them.
Doubtless. What's it say?
That's the problem. It's different than the reading I did this morning, even though the question was the same.
I assume you've shuffled since then. It'd be weird if it wasn't.
Statistically impossible. But Napoleon talked an army into joining him. Anything can happen.
What were you asking the cards?
How likely we are to find the fish we need for the bouillabaisse. At least it confirms my general suspicion: the Morganas are driving away the fish.
Or making an evil bouillabaisse of their own.
Evil bouillabaisse.
I wonder how that would taste.
No, I rather think you don't.
Très étrange. I am not certain what to do.
I hope I'm not interrupting you while you read your tarot cards.
I welcome the company, Capitaine. Perhaps you can help me.
What do you need?
I am reading tarot cards to tell me where to look next for my soup ingredients, but I am stuck.
Ah, right. Tell me more.
See this card? The Seven of Cups. An individual faces seven cups that are floating in a cloud.
I see. Each has something different inside. A dragon, a tower, a wreath, a hooded figure, treasure, a snake, and a human head.
Précisément. What does that tell us?
I think it means...

Fields.MenuText: ... we have a lot of options, so we have to choose carefully.
... we have a lot of opportunities, so we shouldn't overthink it.
... we should start drinking!

Fields.DialogueText: That is what the card tells me, too. Argh! I am paralyzed with so many choices.
Oui, that may be the problem. I am thinking too much.
Ha! Are you telling me that I am too serious? You may be right.
Take a break from this, all right?
Good idea. Perhaps I need a distraction.
*ALARM*
Zut! This is not the distraction I had in mind!
@BATTLE
Je suis désolée, Capitaine. This is all my fault.
It really stinks down there. I heard complaints from the crew, but I didn't realize it was this bad.
Horrible... Tragique... The fish, my precious rascasse rouge, have spoiled. How am I going to make my bouillabaisse now?
Tell me what happened.
I didn't mean to leave the fish in the torpedo room for so long. I got distracted and forgot.

Fields.MenuText: Apologize to the torpedo division. It's going to take weeks to get the smell out of that room.
How can you be obsessed and forgetful about something at the same time?
One of us is going to clean this up, and it's not going to be me.

Fields.DialogueText: Days, Capitaine. Once I set to a challenge I am tireless.
The details of revolution often get lost in the narrative.
Of course. I suppose I can rinse off in the ocean. I can swim as fast as I can sail, you know!
I will personally take care of this mess. That is more than fair.
I'll let you get to it, then.
You may want to steer clear of me for the next few days, Capitaine. If I roll up my sleeves, I expect to dirty my hands.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Less fish guts, more oil and gunpowder.
I'll need it. Even my pomander is powerless against this mess...
Maybe it's just my imagination, but I think I can still smell that rotten fish... even up here in my cabin.
*KNOCK*
Capitaine? Can I come in and talk to you?
Yes, of course, Marseillaise.
Merci.
Oh, Marseillaise. You look...

Fields.MenuText: ... shaken up.
... exhausted.
... miserable.

Fields.DialogueText: Do not worry about me, Capitaine. This was a mess, not a reactionary reprisal.
The mess in the torpedo room was... extensive, Capitaine. It took hard work to fix my mistakes.
I have... had better days.
At least you aren't complaining about how I smell.
I'm concerned about you, not the smell.
My bouillabaisse idea was stupid. I never should have believed that I could-
Stop right there. You can't think like that.
Non. You were right to be critical of my plan. I was idealistic and foolish.
Well...
I just wanted to report that the torpedo room is finally clean.
Thank you.
My obsession with making soup for the crew caused me to neglect my true obligations. I have much work to do.
What next?
I am going to inspect the engine room and verify everything is in good order.
Uh-oh.
@BATTLE
Your concern is very kind, but in this case misplaced. I'm sorry, Capitaine. I deserve this.
*ALARM*
Get to the bridge! We'll discuss this later.
Marseillaise! Wait for me.
Bonjour, Capitaine. What is it?
This thimble fell out of your pocket. Here.
I don't need it. Just throw it away.
You've been littering your knickknacks all over the ship lately. Usually you look after your trinkets better than that.
Perhaps I am outgrowing my obsession with trinkets.

Fields.MenuText: You need to stop punishing yourself here.
What is your problem?
I'd find that more convincing if you didn't look so miserable.

Fields.DialogueText: With all due respect, Capitaine, I disagree.
I should think you would be pleased, Capitaine.
If I felt all the way good about it, I would be missing something.
Instead of wasting my time with foolish ideas, I am more practical now.
I think you're letting one setback kill your spirit.
It was a sign. My bouillabaisse plan was ill-conceived.
I'm not convinced you should give up.
I am. Oh, and if you find any more thimbles or sundries, dispose of them.
*ALARM*
If a revolution lacks focus it's doomed to collapse under its own weight. I refuse to collapse.
She didn't even say her battle cry. This is worse than I thought.
@BATTLE
Capitaine! We have received a distress call!
I heard it. Civilian vessels are being harassed by Morganas, not too far from our position.
Répugnant! Shameful behavior to attack non-combatants! This oppression of the people is unacceptable!

Fields.MenuText: Set a course to the origin of that distress call, flank speed!
It could be a Morgana trap, attacking civilians to draw us out.
Whatever it is, we need to investigate.

Fields.DialogueText: Already done! And not in crayon this time, you'll be please to know.
They don't need to attack civilians to make us appear. I will come out whenever they ask!
Every second we delay is one more for the Morganas to do as they please.
I am sure of one thing, though.
What is what, Capitaine?
I'm glad to see some enthusiasm on your part. Let's get going!
There will be time enough to discuss that later. Aux armes, citoyens!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
It was never gone, Capitaine. Simply put to better use.
Don't forget to save some for yourself.
We're at the source of the distress call, Capitaine!
Looks like Morganas have been attacking the merchants and fishing vessels here without mercy.
Let's end this now! I won't let them hurt any more people here.
@BATTLE
We stopped them! Unlucky for those Morgana witches that we were so close by.

Fields.MenuText: It's always better to be lucky than good.
I don't believe in luck. Everything happens for a reason.
I'm glad we got here in time to help.

Fields.DialogueText: I could use more good luck, Capitaine.
I can't imagine a good reason for Morganas to exist... but I understand what you mean.
I don't even want to think about what we would have found if we hadn't.
Above all else, to serve the people is to heal the soul.
Speaking of serving the people, is there any chance you will serve our crew bouillabaisse someday?
Now who's the obsessed one?
Give it some thought.
I will. Whether I like it or not.
Hey! Look out down there! Get out of the way!
What is the problem, Capitaine?
This fishing boat keeps crossing our path.
I will get us through without hitting them. Do not worry.
Thanks. Having a Belle is great for maneuvering with extra precision.
I am happy to... wait! Capitaine! Look at the fishing boat's name.
Le Chariot?

Fields.MenuText: It reminds me of that old song.
It makes me think of Ben-Hur.
You're thinking of the Tarot card, I assume.

Fields.DialogueText: Non, that is not what I am thinking of.
Quoi? The silent film with the chariot races? No, I am thinking of something else.
Oui! The seventh Major Arcana card.
Perhaps the fishing boat is like a tarot card for me. A sign for me to understand.
*ALARM*
We're about to put that to the test.
No harm shall come to that fishing boat! Protect Le Chariot! Aux armes, citoyens!
@BATTLE
What does it represent?
Facing and defeating challenges. Making a plan and executing it.
And reversed?
Very funny, Capitaine. That boat will not capsize on my watch.
The Morganas were cruel, but Le Chariot is safe for now.
Your defense of that little fishing boat was... spirited.
That boat is a personal message for me, speaking in the language of tarot!

Fields.MenuText: What does that message say?
You're just being superstitious.
Why not talk to them?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not sure. Much of the reading depends on the perspective of the reader.
Indulge me, Capitaine. You have done so before, and look where we are now!
I suppose I could. The Morganas will not try their luck again so quickly.
Well, it looks like they're making the first move.
*HORN*
Hey! Warship! We want to see the Belle that saved us from Morganas!
Your fans are calling for you.
Then take a good look! Here I am! This Belle will always serve the people!
Thank you, fair spirit! Please take some of our fish as a gift!
We insist! We've just had a healthy haul of rascasse...
Whatever will we do with a fresh haul of fish?
Ha! Exciting, non? It seems my superstitions are super indeed!
Really?
@BATTLE
Keep at it! Defend that fishing boat at all costs!
I don't often see you in the galley, Marseillaise.
Hello to you, too, Capitaine. I was checking on the ship's food preparation.
You were quite critical of the food, remember?
Oui, and I still am.
Does this mean Operation Bouillabaisse is back on track?
What if it is, Capitaine? Is that a problem?

Fields.MenuText: Not at all. I'm glad you found your inspiration again.
Same rules as before. Morganas take priority.
Have I ever mentioned that I'm not much of a fan of fish?

Fields.DialogueText: Merci, Capitaine. It is a terrible thing to lose.
Of course! I will not leave this burning, but I will not leave the ship burning either.
Ha! That will change one way or another. You have not tasted mine.
I doubted myself before, but that rascasse windfall proved it. It is my destiny to make that soup! And it will be our crew's destiny to eat it!
Now that we have fish, we really must talk about obtaining the other ingredients.
*ALARM*
You know what that alarm means.
Those Morganas! Don't they know I'm busy planning soup!?
@BATTLE
Marseillaise! Somebody has been drawing on my navigation charts in crayon again!
You sound upset, Capitaine. I suspect it may be the onset of a terrible illness!
It's an illness, all right. I'm sick of finding things tampered with.
I've got just the cure!
Huh?
I have brewed you some special tea that will help you survive this mysterious affliction.

Fields.MenuText: I don't want tea, Marseillaise. I want you to quit drawing on my charts.
Tea? Thanks. Very thoughtful.
I'm not sick!

Fields.DialogueText: Though this be madness, yet there's method in it, as the English say.
You're quite welcome, Capitaine. It tastes better when shared.
I heard, Capitaine, that some diseases have symptoms that include emphatically denying illness.
My stock of curatives is dangerously low. I wrote some nearby ports and marked promising ones as you see.
In blue crayon.
Oui... ports where we can resupply. We must hurry!
So you drew on my charts because you want to make a port call to buy more medicine.
Please, Capitaine! We must! The lives of the entire crew are at stake!
Really?
Well, that, and I need some ingredients for the bouillabaisse.
It would have been easier if you had led with that.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Maybe. But red is my bouillabaisse color!
Maintaining our course, Capitaine. We will arrive in port before long.
You seem quite pleased about that, Marseillaise.
Oui! I am. It is good to have a purpose again.

Fields.MenuText: Being the Belle of a cruiser in wartime isn't enough purpose for you?
We all need a hobby.
This soup had better be amazing.

Fields.DialogueText: That is who I am, Capitaine. Having something to look forward to is something else.
It's more like a mission. What good fortune that missions are my hobby.
That's the only kind of soup I know how to make, Capitaine!
You know that my heart beats for the people, for this crew.
And it's a big heart, Marseillaise. Just don't get carried away.
I promise that I won't. I'll just get my ingredients, get some medicine, and then get back to our combat patrol.
And remember, what's our first priority?
As always, it's-
*ALARM*
Morganas! Now!? How dare they show themselves!
Hey... don't get carried away, remember?
Zut! I will punish them for... for... for delaying the purchase of my groceries!
@BATTLE
Look at all of these delicacies! Saffron, garlic, thyme...
You have a lot of oranges, too. Is that to prevent scurvy?
I need the orange peel to season the bouillabaisse, but the fresh citrus would also be good for the crew to eat. Good thinking!
You're welcome.
I have a small treat that I wanted to share with you. Close your eyes and open your mouth, s'il vous plaît.

Fields.MenuText: I don't like this game.
What is it?
Ahhhhh...

Fields.DialogueText: Trust me, Capitaine. You will like it, I promise.
Please indulge me, Capitaine. You'll be glad you did.
Savor it, then tell me what you think.
Mmm! It's delicious!
I found a merchant who had some excellent mandarin oranges. Since you disliked the bitter one earlier, I thought...
Thanks for sharing that with me, Marseillaise.
Of course. You are most welcome.
*ALARM*
I did not buy any salted pork for Morganas. I have nothing but gunfire for them.
It'd be rude not to share.
@BATTLE
All right. Just this once...
All right...
These Morganas are putting up a spirited fight!
I have faith in you. Give them a run for their money!
@BATTLE
We took a beating in that last fight, but I think we gave them the worst of it.
You're ruthless when dealing with Morganas.
We must be kind to our allies and ruthless to our foes.
Does it ever bother you?
Does what?

Fields.MenuText: Facing danger again and again?
Getting hurt in a fight?
Not knowing when the war will be over?

Fields.DialogueText: Merely the cost of waging a noble battle.
That is not so bad. My hull can be repaired and my guns replaced.
In a way, oui.
I must stay strong for our crew, no matter what, because I want to keep them alive. I want them all, one day, to return home.
We can't always save everyone.
If I had to sacrifice myself, I would do it. Without hesitation. I would rather die than break that faith with my crew.
When you say that, I... I believe you completely.
You ought to! It is the truth.
Really?
You're cooking up a storm in here! It's great to see you finally making this legendary soup.
These ingredients will revitalize our crew. I can almost taste victory!
All of these ingredients must have been expensive.
I had a few trinkets and sundries that I could offer in trade. They were more than enough.

Fields.MenuText: You're always willing to sacrifice for the crew.
I guess your obsession with knick knacks came in handy.
I can try to reimburse you.

Fields.DialogueText: Keepsakes are nice, but they can always buy something good for the here and now.
One man's trash, Capitaine!
That is not necessary, Capitaine. I do not measure their value in francs.
I will do anything for the crew, or for my capitaine.
That's why the crew adores you.
They do?
Of course. Even though you drive them crazy, they genuinely love you.
Do I... drive you crazy, too?
What?
I was just wondering if you feel the same way about me that the crew does.
Oh.
I suppose that-
*ALARM*
Hold that thought! Morganas first, right?
@BATTLE
Right.
Captain, Morganas are due west of us.
Sound the alarm.
@BATTLE
This soup... it's amazing!
Ha! I am glad you are enjoying the bouillabaisse. It is my favorite recipe.
The crew is gulping it down as quickly as you can serve it to them, but there is something I don't understand.
What is that, Capitaine?
The fish is tasty, the spices are wonderful... so why aren't you eating any?
Oh. That's an easy question to answer. I didn't want to get poisoned.

Fields.MenuText: Very funny, Marseillaise.
What!?
We're all going to die together. Start eating right now!

Fields.DialogueText: I am tired from cooking, so my sense of humor might be a little bit strange right now.
I am only teasing. It is perfectly safe.
Ha! You know I am only kidding.
The real answer is that I sampled some while I was cooking. Besides, my pleasure comes from watching the crew enjoy it.
Do you need any help making the next batch?
If you are offering to help me in the galley, then of course you can! Just follow my lead.
*ALARM*
*KNOCK*
Capitaine, you wanted to see me?
Come in.
Reporting as ordered. Oh! It smells like bouillabaisse in here.
The whole ship does, but I don't think anyone minds. Your recipe was a big hit.
Is that why you wanted to see me?
We started a conversation earlier, and we never got to finish it.
We have many conversations, Capitaine. Usually I enjoy them...
That's kind of you.
... except when you complain about me drawing on your navigation charts.

Fields.MenuText: Cause and effect, Marseillaise.

Fields.DialogueText: One or the other of us will get used to it, I expect. Revolutions don't happen overnight.
Right. I never got around to telling you that my feelings are the same.
What are you saying, Capitaine?
You go to every extreme to take care of your people. And you take care of me, as well. I respect you, and consider you my friend.
I feel the same way! During our time together, I have come to regard you as my friend, too.
Well, I'm glad we have that settled. Now, shall we enjoy the peace and quiet before the Morganas rear their ugly heads?
Of course. Could I... get out my tarot cards and do a reading for you, Capitaine?
Heh, sure. Why not?

Fields.MenuText: I'm actually getting to like those drawings. They brighten the charts up.
What if I drew on something you were using?

Fields.DialogueText: Merveilleuse! I mean to make them pretty and easy to read.
I expect it would be prettier for whoever I traded it to.
Oui, I recall that conversation now. It was rudely interrupted by Morganas.
Well, as I was saying, we talked about how the crew profoundly respects you.
